details.title: Commentary: steady-state series-system availability

p: Hoang Pham is an Associate Professor in the Department of Industrial Engineering at Rutgers University. He is the author ofSoftware Reliability (2000, Springer) and editor of the Handbook of Reliability Engineering (2003, Springer). He is the editor-in-chief of the International Journal of Reliability, Quality and Safety Engineering and an associate editor of the IEEE Trans. Systems, Man, and Cybernetics.

authors.name: Hoang Pham

details.abstract: Computation of steady-state series-system availability depends on specific assumptions made about the nonfailed components during the system failure. Sherwin recently made the case that the steady-state availability in a series-system is not calculated using the product rule. This commentary offers a clarification by illustrating 2 cases of steady-state series-system availability that frequently arise in reliability engineering. The product rule is valid for steady-state series-system availability under the circumstances: nonfailed components (viz, electrical components) continue to age "normally" during the repair of the failed component. Therefore, in computing steady-state availability of series-systems, it is important for practitioners to determine whether the nonfailed components continue to age "normally" (case-1) or do not age (case-2). It is also shown that for n/spl ges/2, case-1 steady-state availability of the series-system is smaller than case-2 steady-state series-system availability, and is the same for n=1.

links.abstract: In repairable systems, the steady-state availability is one of the more important factors in specifications and choice of hardware. Some (not all) books, and some expensive courses on reliability, suggest that the steady-state availability of a series system is found by the product rule as for reliability. This is wrong. context.text: [1] states: “Some (not all) books and some expensive courses in reliability, suggest that the steady-state availability of a series-system is found by the product rule as for reliability.
This is wrong.” It continues: “the correct formulation is no more difficult to calculate than the product rule” it is given in [1] 22reference [1]; page 131; equation (1).

The question here is: Is [1], (1) correct, or is the product rule of component availability correct? The answer is: Either one can be correct, depending on the usage of the system's nonfailed components during the system repair time.
